sp.l: No ſhame at all,
For I'll prove it Women are more honeſt now,
And ſin leſs, than they did in former times.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Why? before,
They went to't by ſtealth, but now they do't openly.
There's one ſin leſs, and then there's honeſty
In plain dealing you know.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Th'are much beholding t'ye for defending them ſo well.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Nay, I'll ſtand for th'reputation
Of our Sex, long as I live.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You ſtand for't fairly indeed—But
Here comes the Duke and Dutcheſs.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: 'Beſeech your Highneſs baniſh him the Court,

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We can't in juſtice, on the bare report
Of thoſe your Women, which can't be prov'd, unleſs
Aurindo's ſelf ſhou'd his own crime confeſs.
Beſides, you know, he's our Sons Favorit,
And we don't know how he'll approve of it.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Beſt let him tarry then, till he has made
Luſt and Libidiouſneſs a common trade,
And he at laſt be ſo outragious grown,
To attempt the Chaſtities of every one.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How does this accuſation agree
With's former baſhfulneſs and modeſty?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: More modeſt and baſhful he was before▪
Now makes the crime of falling from't the more.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But none, without firſt paſſing by the mean,
Strait fall from t'on unto the other extream.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: And I cou'd tell you that juſt ſo did he,
Who made th'attempting of their Chaſtity,
Onely a degree unto the attempting mine,
But that l'd not accuſe him of a crime;
For which by th Laws he ought to die.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: If this your accuſation be true,
We'll not onely baniſh him th'Court, but Countrey too.
Nay, take his life for it,—who's there does wait?
Go ſome and ſee him apprehended ſtrait.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But I'll go firſt and prevent it, if I can.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Now, Madam, are you ſatisfied?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I am,
And thank you for your Juſtice; and now, to let you ſee
Y'have but reveng'd your ſelf, as well as me.
Wou'd you believe it? I found him but to day,
Embracing and kiſſing your Emilia?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Call her not mine, for now I hate her more,
Then ever I eſteem'd and lov'd her heretofore;
As by th'revenge I'll take, you ſoon ſhall ſee,
And ſhe ſoon feel—Agenor follow me.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I know not what revenge he means to take▪
But for th'ungrateful Boy, I mean, to make
Him know, before I've done with him, that he
Ruin'd himſelf, when he offended me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: There goes one,
Who proves that nothing's more inſatiate
Than Woman, either in their loves or hate;
And th'are ſtrange Creatures to be pleas'd, no gentle Lamb,
Nor harmleſs Dove was e'er more milde and tame.
Diſpleas'd, no Tyger nor Lion rob'd of s prey,
Was e'er more fell and furious than they—
But ſee unto my wiſh.
Here comes Aurindo.
Oh, Madam, quickly flie,
And ſave your life, it is but loſt elſe.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Let it ſuffice the Dutcheſs ſeeks your life,
That is but loſt, leſs you flie and prevent the danger.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Whoever flies their danger to prevent,
Makes themſelves guilty, though innocent.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: When Princes ſeek their lives, 'tis an offence
To go about to prove their innocence,
Equal to being guilty; wherefore go,
For all the Court is up in ſearch of you,
As on ſome great and general hunting day,
When each one eagerly purſues the prey.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: If this be ſo, I like a hun'ed Deer,
Will flie to Erminia's, and ſhelter there.
For none can better ſave my life, and I
To none wou'd ow my life more willingly.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Go quickly then, and ſave your ſelf as ſecretly as you can—
So now I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Well, and how d'ye like the Moor? our fellow
Servant now?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: Why, as thou'dſt do a reſty jade,
Who wou'd not ſtir a foot for thee;
Or a high metled Horſe,
That when thou ſpur'ſt him, or offer'ſt but to check
The Reins, rears up, and's ready to break thy neck—
Uds ſo, we were deceiv'd in him.
We thought to put all the work of the houſe upon him,
And we may do it our ſelves, for ought I ſee,
You may bid the Poſt do things as well as him,
And the Poſt will ſtir as ſoon too.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: He underſtands you not perhaps.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: I know not,
But I'm ſure I underſtand him but too well—
I gave him a Broom even now,
And 'pointed him where to ſweep
(This was plain enough, now one wou'd imagine)
And what did he, but lay me over the pate
With the Broom-ſtaff,
And ſo he ſerv'd me with a Fire-ſhovel another time.
He'll carry no Coals I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: No? But I'll make him, and h'ad as good eat them too,
As refuſe to do what I bid him; you ſhall ſee
I'll make him fetch and carry like a Water-Spanniel▪
And do tricks like an Ape for me, before l've done with him.
You know not how to handle him.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: Look, here he comes—Let's ſee now.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Mark then—There Sirrah▪ fetch.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: D'ye mark how he fetches and carries for you,
Like a Water-Spanniel.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: He did not ſee it perhaps—Now mark again—
Come over here Sirrah, here—
sp.stage: [Holds out his Arm for him, and leaps over.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: D'ye mark agen,
How he does tricks like an Ape for you?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: No! But I'll make him, if he will not—
—Why how now Sirrah, muſt I be troubled with ye?
S'led I think I ſhall be troubled with him indeed—
sp.stage: [Takes him by the Shoulder, and he takes him by the Throat.
sp.l: Help, help Clymias.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: Not I be-ſhrew me,
There's none knows how to handle him
But your ſelf, you know.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The Divel ſhall handle him for me,
If he be ſuch an one—
Vengeance on your Claws, and hooked Talons;
He grip'd me worſe than a Lion does its Prey,
Or a Hawk its Quarry.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Now, what's here to do?
You have been vexing the Moor I ſee.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: No indeed, forſooth, he has rather been vexing us.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Go too, and meddle with him no more, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: With all our hearts, ſo he'd meddle no more with us.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Now, how goes it?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: O Friend, the Storms and Tempeſts of my Breſt,
By no compariſons can be expreſt;
Neither with thoſe on Land, when Winds do blow,
As Fabrick of the World they'd overthrow;
Or thoſe at Sea, when Waves do riſe ſo high,
You'd think their very Billows touch'd the Skie—
For her being viſited by the Prince and Duke,
That now's a thing I eaſily cou'd brook.
But to be viſited by a Villain-Page,
And kiſs'd and embraced too, does ever enrage
Me unto madneſs—

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.l: And ſhall we never then be rid of him?
There is no way, but kill him.
div.stage: Offers to draw, but is withheld.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Yet again?
There are hundred others, beſides killing him,
And there's no neceſſity to do that, which we
Shou'd never do for any neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Fear not, but be aſſur'd whil'ſt you are here,
You are as ſafe, as you at Argos were;
And I aſſure my ſelf this place, and you
Shall be as free from violation too.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: It were ſo high ſacriledge, to violate
A place, Madam, your preſence does conſecrate▪
I ſhou'd aſſoon the violation fear,
In Heaven it ſelf, of Saints and Angels there.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: If any thing, render you free from violence,
'Tis not I, nor th'place, but onely your innocence.
For more ſecurity yet,
I'll lock you up here in my Cabinet,
Mean time, pray think it not a priſon, but
Rather a Sanctuary where y'are put.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I think ſo, Madam, or if't a priſon be▪
To be your priſoner's above all liberty.
sp.stage: She locks her up, then goes the other way.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Well then, I ſee
My Lady will get Aurindo away from me,
And then ſhe kills me quite;
For who takes my coyn, does but as robbers do,
Who takes my love, robs me, and kills me too.
I ſhall remember this.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Well—What think you?
Are theſe fit Cabinet pieces for Ladies now?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Till more of her intention I know,
I cannot tell, whether they or no. t,
For oft for want of knowing their inten
We judge thoſe guilty who are innocent.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Won't you have me believe my eyes, and what I ſee?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Believe your eyes, but not your jealouſie;
Which like the Jauneſs, ſo infects our ſight
With colour of't, we nothing ſee aright.
And mark the count'nance of the Boy, 'twas fear
Rather than love, it ſeems, did bring him here.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Nay, then we ſhall ne'er have done—But who have we here,
More Viſitants?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: The Duke has ſent me on a Meſſage here,
I wou'd ſome other, rather than I might bear.
But who by Princes are commanded, they
Muſt not diſpute their pleaſures, but obey—
Is your Lady within?

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Pray tell her then, there
'S a Meſſenger from th'Duke deſires to ſpeak with her.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: What meſſage ſhou'd this be?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I'll lay my life,
Some amorous one or other to my wife.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Now Sir, your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis ſuch I fear,
Will go nigh to break your heart, when you ſhall hear.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Imagine but the worſt that can be ſed,
A nd it is that—my Lord your Husband's dead.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How dead!

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Why, caſt away at Sea,
And drown'd in his return from Attica.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: My Lord and Husband dead?
Nay then, I've liv'd too long.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Bravely counterfeited on all ſides.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Why, Madam, Madam.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: This wou'd be the effect,
O'th'news I brought, I ever did ſuſpect;
But I muſt go and tell the Duke of it.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Help for ſhame here, will you let her die,
When you may remedy it ſo eaſily,
By diſcovering you are alive.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Paw Man, I know
An eaſier way to remedy it than ſo.
Let us but go and leave her here alone,
No Woman e'er died for grief, when ſhe was alone.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Why Madam, Madam, what mean you? will you die
For a falſe report? Calimachus live's, upon
My life he does.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Ay, in t'other world where I,
Will preſently go to bear him company.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Nay in this, and if I ſhew
You him not alive e'er to morrow, ne'er truſt me more.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: You ſay this onely to comfort me now.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I do ſo Madam, and what I've ſed,
I will make good, wherefore be comforted.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Why the Duke ſhou'd do this, I do not know,
Unleſs to be reveng'd on me; if ſo,
'Tis but a poor revenge to tell a lie,
Which like falſe Coyn's diſcover'd preſently.
And when diſcover'd, turns to th' Authors ſhame,
And gets them onely a baſe Liers name.
What ever his intention was, I'll fit
Him for't, and ſeem as I believed it.
So ſhall I innocently revenged be,
And deceive thoſe, who'd have deceiv'd me.

div.head: SCENE IX.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: O Clymias,
We have loſt the beſt Maſter as ever ſervants had!
Oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: 'Tis true indeed, but never cry for that;
We did not all come together, and ſhall not
All go together, you know.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: How ever we muſt cry now, Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Theſe people cry in conſert;
What a caterwawling they make?

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Oh, my Lord, my Lord, what ſhall I do? what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Why prithee, hold thy peace, and make not ſuch a noiſe.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Why, are your ears ſo dainty? they can endure no noiſe, I pray?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Nay, prithee don't leave crying, and fall to ſcolding now.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Scold! Who ſcolds I pray? Goodly goodly!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Will 'thold thy peace then?

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Perhaps I will, perhaps I wont, what's that to you?
May'nt one ſpeak for you, I pray? no wonder indeed?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Agen! Twenty Pies and Jays,
Taken in Lim-twigs, make not ſuch a chattering noiſe,
As one Woman when ſhe ſets upon it once.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: O, my Lord, my Lord, what ſhall I do? what ſhall I do.

div.stage: Enter Emilia the other way in Mourning.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: So, now let them come
When e'er they pleaſe, I am prepar'd for them;
Nor can they ſay
I fain, to mourn his death whil'ſt he's away;
For death, and abſence, onely differ in this,
This a ſhort death, that, a long abſence is.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Madam the Prince is here without.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I look'd for him—
Go preſently then, conduct him in.
If all things in this viſit falls out right.
I may finde means to ſerve the Princeſs by't.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Madam, to omit the common Ceremony
Of Comforting▪ and of Condoling w'ye▪
Which Verbal Comforts rather do increaſe
Our Griefs and Sorrows, than any ways make leſs.
Inſtead of that, I bring you a real one,
And in lieu of your dead Lord, offer you a living one.
And ſuch an one, I without boaſt may ſay,
Equals the dead Calimachus every way.
I mean my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I'm glad of this—
And more, my Lord, in deeds to anſwer you,
Than words, againſt the common cuſtom too
Of other Widows, who when their Lords are dead,
Refuſe by any means—to be comforted,
But ſigh and weep in company, when they
But laugh, perchance, when company's away:
Were I aſſur'd your meaning real were—

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: As real as that of dying Men, I ſwear.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Come to my Chamber in the dark to night
(For yet my ſhame can hardly brook the light,)
And there the ſacred words of marriage paſt,
And hands to hands, as hearts to hearts made faſt—
I ſay no more, you underſtand the reſt

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I do, and count my ſelf, moſt highly bleſt.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Look then you do not fail.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Which if I do▪
May life, nay what is more, you fail me too.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Go, and make haſt then.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Wou'd day wou'd go as faſt,
And this moſt happy night, make half that haſte

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: So now
Will I dreſs the Princeſs in womans cloaths,
That ſo i th dark he may deceived be,
And marry her, when he comes inſtead of me—
Pardon me ſacred Truth, thou know'ſt that 'tis
Not, to violate thy Laws, that I do this.
But for a greater good 'tis onely done,
To ſave thy Laws from Violation.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Hey da! this is fine,
The Prince and Page too! She might have left
Me him, at leaſt, to be piddling with Ifaith.
But ſince ſhe has ſo little Conſcience,
I'll have as little.
And go, and tell the Dutcheſs all; ſo ſhall I be
Reveng'd on her, for diſobliging me.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Why, here's brave haſt!
Never was Widows mourning ſooner paſt,
Nor ever Widow ſooner married

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I tell you, ſhe knows you are not dead,
And there's ſome plot in't.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ay, the plot is clear,
The Prince to night's to come and marry her,
'Leſs I forbid the Banes, which I ſhall do,
And ſome of them ſhall dearly pay for't too.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Then I muſt tell you, with liberty of a Friend,
This way your jealouſie ne'er will have end.
If you continue to interpret thus,
Toth'worfer ſence all that ſhe ſays and does▪

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Whilſt you interpret all to the beſt, and I
To th'worſt.
It follows neceſſarily in this affair,
Nor you, nor I, compotent Judges are.
Wherefore, till ſome more competent we get,
Let it alone, and talk no more of it:
But pray, go to the Port, and if perchance
Any arrive, may give intelligence
That I am here, divert them dext'rouſly,
Till I have finiſh'd my diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: I ſhall, though I'm loath to leave you here a'one,
Leaſt you ſhou'd take occaſion, when I am gone
To do what y've ſo oft attempted.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Never fear, but be aſſur'd I'll nothing do,
But what in honor I am bound unto.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: This point of honor is a thing ſo nice,
Sometimes it may be Vertue, ſometimes Vice;
Sometimes be bad, ſometimes agen be good,
According as 'tis rightly underſtood.
And oft for want of underſtanding't right,
'Stead of being honor'd, w'are diſhonor'd by't.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Go, go, you are ſo cautious ſtill for me,
I'll underſtand it as I ought, you'll ſee—
So, I'm glad I've ſhifted him away—
For what w'are reſolved to do, it is not fit
To let them know, may hinder th'doing it;
And he's of too milde diſpoſition,
To know my deſperate reſolution—
For firſt, I'm reſolv'd the Boy ſhall die, he ne'er
Shall live to boaſt the favors he 'has from her.
Then ſince I
Am dead to her, ſhe ſhall be dead to me.
And th'hour of her marriage with the Prince, ſhall be
Her hour of death.
My honor is engaged in it, and I
Am abſolutely reſolv'd that ſhe ſhall die.
This hand ſhall kill her—Theſe eyes ſhall ſee't,
Although this heart burſt at the ſight of it.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: THanks Althea, and th'Duke ſhall thank thee too
For thy intelligence. I'll but onely go
Inform him of it, and ſtraight follow thee:
Mean time go home, and look you ready be,
To give us entrance when we come.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Gle.
sp.l: The more Traytor you.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: I was afraid he had eſcap'd by flight,
And ſo had fruſtrated my anger by't.
But now I'll let him know
My anger's none of theſe light blazing fires,
Which gives a flaſh or two, and then expires.
But Elementary Fire that's its own
Fewel and flame, and ne'er does leſs become.
And this his flying to Emilias,
My fire of Anger more incenſed has.
As if h'had ſuch confidence in her, or elſe ſhe
Such power to defend his life, and him from me.
So this is all he has obtain'd by flight,
To make himſelf, and cauſe more guilty by't;
And where before leſs puniſhment might ſuffice,
Now, without mercy, 'tis reſolv'd he dies.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Alas poor Aurindo! Introth, I pitty him.
But this is a juſt judgment on him now,
For his making me looſe my longing, when time was—
Wou'd I had ſome body to tell this news to now,
For never any Collick, Strangury,
Nor other retentive diſeaſe; no not the pangs
Of child-birth it ſelf, was ever half ſo painful
As the Retention of news, to one who longs
To be deliver'd of it.

sp.speaker: O Olindo,
sp.l: have you heard the news?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: No, what news?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I'll tell you—But you muſt ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Pho, you know
No dying body holds things faſter than I
Do ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Why▪ Aurindo whom we thought was fled,
Is yonder at Emilia's diſcovered,
And th'are ſending to apprehend him.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Alas? He is but dead then,
And I could finde in my heart to beg his life.
But for bringing my Maiden head in queſtion▪
Wou'd I had ſome body.
To tell this to—O Agenor, have you heard the news?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: What news?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Why, I'll tell you—But you muſt ſay nothing.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: That's underſtood.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Why, Aurindo is apprehended at Emiliaes,
And is now at his arraignment▪

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: There he has added that unto it now.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: This will be news unto Cleanthes here—

sp.speaker: O Cleanthes,
sp.l: have you heard the news of Aurindo?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: What of him?

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Why, he's condemn'd to death,
And juſt now th'are leading him to execution.

sp.speaker: Clea▪
sp.l: Nay then 'tis time to diſcover who ſhe is—
I'll preſently to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: There he has added another circumſtance more to't!—This is fine Embrodery.
There wants onely his ſpeech on the Scaffold now,
To make the news compleat.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Ifaith, Ifaith, I ſee you men,
Can as little hold ſecrets as we women.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: But of all women, commend me to you—
Did I tell you Aurindo was apprehended?
And to be try'd for his life?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: And did I tell you! That he was already condemn'd to die,
And juſt now leading to his execution?
And did not you promiſe me to ſay nothing?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And you me?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Ay, that was before I heard it;
But after, I cou'd not hold no more than you,
Whom, I know wou'd have burſt, if you had not come out with it.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Well, I'll take heed
How I tell you any more ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Mean time, I'll go and tell this to all I meet?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ay, will you ſo? But you ſhall run for't then.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: A pleaſant contention?
But I'll go to Emilia's to know,
Where this news of Aurindo be true or no.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: Why this Moor's a Devil;
And now I know the reaſon, why they paint
The Devil of his colour—He makes no more of beating us,
Then Hammer-men do of Anvels, or Hemp-beaters
Of beating Hemp. 'Tis his ordinary exerciſe
Before meals, to get him an appetite,
And afterwards to help digeſtion.
We are never at quiet for him, but in our ſleep;
And ſhortly I look to have him fall upon us,
Like a Night-mare in our ſleep too.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: This was your fault, for why
Wou'd you offer to beat him?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: Why, becauſe I thought he wou'd not beat me again,
Elſe I'd have ſeen him hang'd,
E'er I'd have meddled with him.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Well, there's no way now,
But to hold together, for Hercules, they ſay,
Is not ſtrong enough for two.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: Ay, but if he ſhou'd prove ſtronger then Hercules now,
That old ſaying wou'd do us but little good.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I ll warrant you—And ſee where he comes here.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: Look he becomes us away.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ay—But let's not ſtir for him—
Yes, I warrant you, when can you tell?

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: Uds ſo—Wo unto us now,
For he has got a ſtaff.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: No matter, let us but hold together,
And look you that ways, whil'ſt I look this,
For fear of a ſurpriſe, and there's no danger.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: I am terribly afraid though,
For my left Buttock never itches, but I
Am ſure of a beating—Now, now; he comes, he comes—
Oh, oh, oh!
sp.stage: He yokes his Staff about their necks, and whirls them about.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Now will I go kill the Boy.
sp.stage: Throws away his Staff, and Exit▪

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: Devil take him, a my Conſcience h'as broke my neck.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And mine's but little better. Shame on you, are theſe your tricks.
If he hold on, he'll make more work for Surgeons,
Than twenty drunken quarrels.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: He made me ſpin like a top.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And I imagin'd my ſelf
A Hand-mill grinding Muſtard-ſeed.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: If he could but ſpeak
And give us but a reaſon, yet for his beating us,
'Twou'd never anger me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: No. 'tis better as it is,
For if I he cou'd ſpeak, 'twere but a word and a blow with him,
I know him well enough.

sp.speaker: Cly.
sp.l: But behold my Lady.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Then let us be gone.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Emilia, Aurindo after in Womans attire.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Now having given order without,
For reception of the Prince, I'll in and ſee
If the Princeſs be ready yet—
There is a certain pleaſure in doing good,
By none but thoſe who do it underſtood;
And 'tis redoubled then, when 'tis done to thoſe
Are moſt deſerving of the good one does—
Where are you Madam?—
Why now you look like your ſelf, juſt as the Sun
When after long Ecclipſe he here does come,
Cheering this other Hemiſphere with light;
And with his preſence makes a day of night.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Nay, now you flatter me.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Flatter you thoſe who can,
Who are ſo far above it,
As thoſe ſhou'd rather be counted envious, who
Don't praiſe you, than flatterers who do—
Where was the Princes judgment I wonder? where
His eyes? That after he had ſeen this Beauty here,
He could ever look on any other?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: He might well be excus'd, having ſeen your Beauty once,
To have quite forgotten mine.

sp.speaker: Em
sp.l: Nay, now you flatter me—
Stay, let me help you a little.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Excuſe me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Beſeech you, y'are not us'd
To dreſs your ſelf I know.

sp.speaker: Aur
sp.l: Nor you to dreſs others.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: 'Pray, Madam, be merry,

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Alas! how can I be merry,
Being to undertake an action;
In which the wiſe, and raſh, are mingled ſo,
How to diſtinguiſh them, I do not know.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Now let me put on your vail, and all is well—
Why do ye tremble ſo?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: How I can chuſe but fear?
Conſidering in what danger I am here,
And how I indanger you, ſhou'd they but know,
How you conceal me here?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I'll warrant you—Ha! what noiſe is that?

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: The Moor ruſhes in with's Sword drawn, Palemon after, &c.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Some come to apprehend me!

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Fly then ſtrait
Into my Cloſſet.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: What's this I ſee? The Boy gone, and a Woman in his place?
There's witchcraft in it ſure? And I can't believe my eyes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: What noiſe was this? Ha!
The Moor here and 's Sword drawn! Help, help.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: What means theſe cryes Madam?

sp.speaker: Em
sp.l: Do you not ſee
The Moor with's Sword drawn? Ready to murther me?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: If that be all, Madam, behold he's gone,
And it's onely your imagination.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Never tell me, nor excuſe him, I know
The danger I was in, and it was more than ſo.
Wherefore ſee preſently he be ſent away,
For I'm reſolv'd he ſhall no longer ſtay;
Who now of late is grown ſo dangerous,
There's no induring him longer in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Have but patience, Madam, till my Lord comes home,
And then I promiſe you he ſhall be gone.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Well—ſo long I'll ſuffer him, ſince you have promis'd me,
That e'r to morrow I ſhou'd ſee my Lord,
And I expect you ſhou'd make good your word.
sp.stage: [Exit, and Calimachus appears at other ſide.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: What have you done ſince I went hence? That ſhe
Is ſo implacably offended w'ye,
She'll never more endure your ſight again?

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Truth is, I thought to have kill'd the Boy; and when
I came, but think how great my wonder was,
To finde him gone, and a Woman in his place!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: You ſee from hence, how y'are miſtaken ſtill,
And how your jealouſie deceives you, yet you will believe it ſtill.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Well, hereafter I will be
More wary, mean time, what news from th' Port with ye?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: All the news that's there, is y'are return'd, and that y'are ſomewhere here
Conceal'd in Town; wherefore, or preſently
Diſcover your ſelf, or they'll diſcover ye,
And let her know your ſelf, what ſhe will know
From others ſhortly, whether you will or no.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Have but patience till night, when I ſhall know
Whether I've reaſon for my jealouſie, or no;
Which of all the wounds incurable they call,
Is one of the moſt incurable of all.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Ne'er ſay ſo; for there's none but cur'd may be,
So onely they'll apply the remedy.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Ah never, never that, but be aſſur d,
Hurt Honor may be ſalv'd, but never cur'd.
And thoſe are living, it no more won'd ſtead,
Than ſalving of their wounds, wou'd thoſe are dead.
You have heard the aſſignation
Sh'as made the Prince, to marry him anon;
And as I ſee the iſſue of this night,
So I ſhall know to take my meaſures right.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: Well, ſince y'are ſo reſolv'd, I'll leave you; and I
Muſt onely be ſorry for what I can't remedy.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I wou'd to Heaven this fatal night were paſt.
That I might know what to reſolve at laſt.
For ſince firſt hour of my jealouſie,
No damn'd Soul ever ſuffer'd more than I▪
And now by dear experience I finde,
There is no torment to a troubled minde.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: My Lady ſets me here
To watch the Princes coming,
And I hope he'll give me a good reward for it;
For my Palm itches for it,
As a Phyſitian or Lawyers for their fees,
And that's a good ſign, however I ſhall nothing leeſe;
For when the Duke and Dutcheſs comes, I expect agen
A reward from them, for the betraying him.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Oh here comes the Prince.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Now I am come
'Twixt willingneſs and unwillingneſs I finde,
Thought of Irena comes into my minde;
And how I go to give away to night,
That to another, which onely is her right.
But 't ſhou'd have ſooner come, or not at all.
For now it is too late, and my minde is all
Upon Emilia—Now Althea, where's your Lady?

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Within my Lord in her Chamber, expecting you i'th' dark.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: No matter, my Love, the way will find,
As well 'th' dark as light, for Love is blind.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: I'll lead you to the door, and need not tell you,
How I've always been a ready ſervant to your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I know it well,
And thank you for't.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: So, I know, at leaſt, where to have him now,
Although the Boy be vaniſht, I know not how.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: How's this! I know it well, and thank you for't.
Theſe anſwers now, me thinks, do come far ſhort
Of thoſe he was wont to give me heretofore,
When every word with Gold was guilded o'er.
By which I ſee, men give more (howe'er it comes,)
For unlawful pleaſures, than for lawful ones.
But now I talk of pleaſure,
I have long had a mind uuto this Moor,
And never had opportunity before,
To finde him alone—Come then
My pretty ſwarthy Rogue, let you and I
Have a little more familiarity—
sp.stage: She offers to embrace him, and he ſhoves her away ſo rudely as ſhe falls.
sp.l: A ſhame on you!
Is this your familiarity with a vengeance,
You black Shag-dog, you ugly Devil you,
I cou'd find in my heart to claw out his eyes—
Beſhrew
His heart for it for me—I fear
There's ſomewhat out of joynt in my Crupper here.

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: The Duke, Dutcheſs, Cleanthes, Agenor, Cleora, Olinda, &c.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Away, away,
You tell me a ſtory ſo improbable,
I'd believe the Metamorphoſes as well
Aurindo Princeſs of Argos!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I can aſſure your Highneſs 'tis moſt true;
Wherefore by the Laws of Nations, you
Are to preſerve her perſon inviolate.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We know well enough, what w'are to do for that,
And how far to preſerve her inviolate; for when
We have Aurindo, take you the Princeſs then.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And when you have him, you will eaſily know,
Whether it be Aurindo or ſhe, or no.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Where is Emiliaes Chamber?
Break open the door there?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Stay, firſt knock, and if they open it not,
Then do as y'are commanded, break it open.

sp.speaker: Within Pr.
sp.l: Who knocks there?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: 'Tis I, the Duke.

sp.speaker: Within Pr.
sp.l: Then pleaſe your Highneſs onely ſtay a while,
And I'll come out.

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: The Prince and Aurindo vailed, Calimachus at t'other door, &c.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Fear not deareſt now, you are mine, there's none
Shall dare to touch or injure you.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: You my Son?
Rather my ſhame, who might have married
A Soveraign Princeſs, to take unto your Bed,
An ordinary perſon, and a ſubject now.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Nay worſe, a baſe diſhonorable woman too.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Now will I kill her even in the Princes Arms.
sp.stage: [Offers to draw firſt, as ſhe unvails.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I am not baſe, nor diſhonorable, but one
As noble, and honorable as any, excepting none.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: How's this? Aurindo, a Woman!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I told you ſo.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: The Princeſs of Argos!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: The ſame,
And now your wife.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: I ſhall die for very ſhame
Of my inconſtancy.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Now 'tis clear,
My Erminia is true, and I falſly ſuſpected her.
Wherefore—I'll inſtantly
Go ask her pardon for my jealouſie.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: What makes him go ſo faſt
Towards my Ladies Chamber, I wonder!
I'll follow and ſee.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: And can you pardon me ſweet?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I can pardon any thing, but your doubt of it.
My fear is, you'l never truſt me more, when you
Conſider but how I have deceiv'd you now.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: Oh more, far more, for you now have but done
Like ſome charitable Phyſitian,
Who for to cure ſome wayward Patient,
Is forc't a hundred ſtratagems to invent.
Which being cur'd, he thankfully does confeſs,
And asks their pardon for his waywardneſs.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Madam, though now I'll not excuſe
My former love to Aurindo, nor ſay agen
It was the Princeſs that I lov'd, not him
Yet now I may truly ſay,
I love the Princeſs more
Then ever I did Aurindo heretofore.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: And I, Madam, am doubly obliged to you
For the love you bore me then,
And that you bear me now.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.l: But where's Erminia, who has ſo happily
Deceived me?

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Why, you ſhall finde her in the Moors arms there within,
He embracing her, and ſhe embracing him.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: That we ſhall ſtrait-ways know.
Go ſome of you fetch them forth; and if't be ſo,
The Moor ſhall die, what e'er becomes of her.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: This does to me ſo impoſſible appear
That ſhe ſo much her honor ſhou'd forget,
I'd not believe mine eyes, though they did ſee't.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: Now don't you ſee them?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Bring them, bring them away,
And is this the chaſt, and vertuous Emilia?
Who ſtood ſo highly on her honor, ſhe
Had rather die, than forfeit her chaſtity,
That now's all proſtitute to that Villain there,
Who from her Bravo's, become her Adulterer—
To the Croſs with him.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: And let her live▪ with ſhame,
Of being branded with a ſtrumpets name.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Stay—and rather then her honor ſhou'd ſuffer by't,
The dumb ſhall ſpeak, and Ethiope turn white.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How! Calimachus the Moor? I'm loſt in the diſmay
Of the ſtrange changes I have ſeen to day!

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: And now, I crave your Highneſs pardon,
That ſince the Wars in Attica are done,
Without your Licence I'm returned home▪

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Y'have merited ſo much whil'ſt you were there▪
You can do nothing I ſhou'd not pardon here.
And I ſhou'd ask your pardon too, that I
So far have tryed Emilia's conſtancy,
But that you know, with no other intention
But onely to try her conſtancy 'twas done.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I know it well, my Lord—or it is beſt
To ſeem to know no otherwiſe at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And now, Madam, here our jealouſie ends
Of Aurindo and Emilia, and we are friends.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.l: And Emilia and I no leſs.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Nay, leave your fleering, for you and I muſt part,
You know I've given you warning.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: With all my heart;
For then—I hope your Highneſs, at leaſt, will entertain me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Not I, I promiſe you; for ſhe
Who's falſe to her, will ne'er be true to me.

sp.speaker: Alt.
sp.l: Well then—My comfort is, when ſervices won't do,
I have a good Trade, at leaſt, to truſt unto.

sp.speaker: Cy.
sp.l: We are heartily glad your Lordſhip is return'd
And your ſelf agen; for you don't beat us half ſo much
When y'are our Lord, as when y'are our fellow-ſervant.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Nor you don't deſerve it half ſo much neither.
But we too much forget Palemon here,
Who has always been a faithful friend to me;
And you have not a truer friend than he.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Noble Palemon I do know ſo well,
What he's to you and me, you need not tell.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.l: And I'm ſo much ſervant to you and him,
I know not which o'th' two I moſt eſteem.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: As for you, Madam, y'are as welcome here,
As if you in your own Dominions were;
And 'tis indeed your own Dominion
Since Argos and Micena now are both but one.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: What e'er I am at Argos, I deſire
To be your Highneſs humble ſervant here.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Well then—Farewel Calimachus, and cheriſh Emilia there;
For I on tryal thus can of her,
That honor and ſhe are twins.
And ſo alike 'twere no miſtake to ſay,
Emilia is Honor, and Honor Emilia.

lg.l: WE can't but think what cenſuring there will be
Know, of this our Tragi-Comedy.
Whil'ſt ſome will praiſe this in it, and ſome that
Others again diſpraiſe they know not what.
Mean time for us (though t'rarely does befal)
It is our hopes, that it pleaſe you all,
If it be poſſible (for now 'tis come
To that) 'tis held impoſſible to be done.
Your humors are ſo different, and you
So different in your opinions too.
As for our Author, all he bad us ſay,
Was onely this, for Epilogue to our play,
That if it do not pleaſe you now, he's ſorry;
And if it do, he's glad he has it for ye.
